results.name: Number of solutions to x^2 + y^2 + z^2 == 0 (mod n).
comment: To show that a(n) is multiplicative is simple number theory. If gcd(n,m)=1, then any solution of x^2 + y^2 + z^2 == 0 (mod n) and any solution (mod m) can combined to a solution (mod nm) using the Chinese Remainder Theorem and any solution (mod nm) gives solutions (mod n) and (mod m). Hence a(nm) = a(n)*a(m). - _Torleiv Kløve_, Jan 26 2009
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000 (first 80 terms from Robert Gerbicz)
C. Calderón and M. J. De Velasco, On divisors of a quadratic form, Boletim da Sociedade Brasileira de Matemática, Vol. 31, No. 1 (2000), pp. 81-91; alternative link.
László Toth, Counting Solutions of Quadratic Congruences in Several Variables Revisited, J. Int. Seq., Vol. 17 (2014), Article # 14.11.6; arXiv preprint, arXiv:1404.4214 [math.NT], 2014.
Index to sequences related to sums of squares
formula: a(2^k) = 2^(k + ceiling(k/2)). For odd primes p, a(p^(2k-1)) = p^(3k-2)*(p^k + p^(k-1) - 1) and a(p^(2k)) = p^(3k-1)*(p^(k+1) + p^k - 1). - _Martin Fuller_, Jan 26 2009
Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) ~ (4*zeta(3))/(15*zeta(4)) * n^3 + O(n^2 * log(n)) (Calderón and de Velasco, 2000). - _Amiram Eldar_, Mar 04 2021
